poem:
A Flicker of Hope  

Tent shudders—  
flicker grows beneath  
bomb-battered sky,  
a breath held  
between silences.  
  
In the sand's whisper  
lies the tread of peace  
unsteady, elusive.  
  
Here, hope  
rises like dust,  
settles back  
as the sky  
turns to thunder.  
Still, a heartbeat  
echoes: wait.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I feel like we are in a trap’: Gaza residents hopeful but wary of Trump’s plan When Arij al-Farra heard that Hamas had partially agreed to Donald Trump’s plan and that the US president had ordered Israel to stop bombing Gaza, the first thing she felt was a flicker of hope. The second thing she felt was an explosion. An Israeli aircraft had dropped a bomb close to her tent in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
